NoteLiteral.En:
Entry requirements:
•	Student at any of the universities of the ECIU;
•	B2 level of English language proficiency.
Applicants need to attach a copy of ID card / passport (document issued by the country of origin) to enrol in the KTU virtual learning environment. This does not apply to KTU students (if you are a KTU student, you may attach a blank page).
Students, who are admitted and accepted the offered place in the micro-module, will be informed by email on the steps to take in order to gain access to the KTU virtual learning environment. Students will receive an email from the teacher of the micro-module on the first day of the start of module.
Students who have dropped out from the KTU micro-module(s) in the autumn 2024 are not eligible to enrol in the KTU micro-module(s) in the spring 2025.

Description.En:
Disruptive technologies have dramatically reshaped the landscape of go-to-market strategies in the last decade. Emerging technologies, such as AI, IoT, and blockchain, have not only accelerated the pace of innovation but have also altered the fundamental approaches to bringing products and services to market. In the recent past, traditional strategies often followed a linear path, where companies meticulously planned product development, market entry, and scaling processes. Today, with the advent of disruptive technologies, this linear approach is no longer sufficient. Instead, we witness a more dynamic, agile, and customer-centric approach.

One significant change is the speed of adaptation. Disruptive technologies require companies to swiftly pivot and experiment with their strategies. They encourage a 'fail-fast' mentality, where iterations and learning from mistakes are integral to success. Moreover, data-driven decision-making is now at the core of modern go-to-market strategies. The rise of digital platforms and e-commerce has also transformed the reach and accessibility of markets. Companies can now tap into global audiences with minimal physical presence. This shift is forcing traditional brick-and-mortar businesses to reimagine their models.

The target audience for this micro-module primarily includes individuals such as students, researchers, and entrepreneurs who possess backgrounds outside of business administration or business development. This micro-module is particularly well-suited for those with engineering backgrounds, but it is equally open to individuals from natural and social sciences. Disruptive innovations often find applications across various fields, making this micro-module relevant and beneficial for a wide range of professionals.

NoteLiteral.En: Student will learn to define and recognize the innovation, as differentiating between sustained and disruptive innovation types
Student will learn to understand and apply the innovator’s method as a tool to manage demand and technology uncertainties
Student will learn how to lead the team of innovators while maintaining creativity and avoiding self-disruption of a team
Student will learn to recognize and apply modern business models, creating the best conditions for the clients to part with their money

MoreInformation.NoteLiteral:
There are video lectures of one or several parts (lasting 10 to 15 minutes each) for each topic. Each video lecture is followed by lecture slides and a chapter of reading material. After the lecture each week there is a discussion forum, which is mandatory to participate. Participation in the weekly discussions will be graded and will make 5% of the final grade each (20% total over four weeks). At the end of each week there is a quiz. For each quiz learners are given a mark, which makes 15% of the final grade (60% total over four weeks). At the end of the micromodule students are asked to prepare and upload highly concentrated (less than 1 page) idea report. The grade for a report will make 20% of the final grade.

[Syllabus of the micro-module](https://uais.cr.ktu.lt/ktuis/stp_report_ects.mdl_ml?p_kodas=MM00M119&p_year=2024&p_lang=EN&p_stp_id=)

The micro-module will be delivered in the KTU virtual learning environment. When a student is enrolled in KTU, s/he will be informed by email on how to gain access to the micro-module.  

After the successful completion of the micro-module:

- In two weeks, a student will receive an email with the link to download the ECIU University micro-credential.
- In mid-June 2025, a student from other university than KTU will receive an email with the KTU Transcript of Records that might be presented for recognition of learning outcomes at the home university.
Ignite your potential and transform tomorrow with the power of innovation

The aim is to empower you with the tools and mindset required to harness the potential of disruptive innovation, transforming challenges into opportunities for groundbreaking success.

The most important aspect of this micro-module is its focus on equipping you with practical skills and strategic insights that enable you to lead innovation and drive impactful change in your field. This course is designed not only to broaden your knowledge but also to inspire you to apply innovative solutions to real-world problems, ultimately making a tangible difference in society.

Entry requirements:

- Student at any of the universities of the ECIU;
- B2 level of English language proficiency.

Applicants need to attach a copy of ID card / passport (document issued by the country of origin) to enrol in the KTU virtual learning environment. This does not apply to KTU students (if you are a KTU student, you may attach a blank page).

Students, who are admitted and accepted the offered place in the micro-module, will be informed by email on the steps to take in order to gain access to the KTU virtual learning environment. Students will receive an email from the teacher of the micro-module on the first day of the start of module.

Students who have dropped out from the KTU micro-module(s) in the autumn 2024 are not eligible to enrol in the KTU micro-module(s) in the spring 2025.
